Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Resonance and Inductive Effects in Fundamental Chemical Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Chemistry division, Professor Joel Karty of Elon University will determine the energetic contributions by resonance and inductive effects toward the driving force behind a variety of fundamental organic reactions. The project will incorporate both experimental and computational methodologies. In the experimental methodology, reaction kinetics and thermodynamics will be determined for a variety of reactions involving homologs of the species of interest. The results will then be extrapolated to arrive at the values involving the species of interest. One computational methodology, called a vinylogue extrapolation methodology, incorporates a similar strategy, by utilizing standard molecular orbital theory calculations to determine resonance and inductive contributions toward reactions involving homologs of the species of interest. The second computational methodology is a block-localized wavefunction methodology, the simplest variation of valence bond theory, which allows for the calculations of resonance energies directly. The broader impacts largely surround teaching and training undergraduates in chemistry research, and in the dissemination of that knowledge via publication in major journals, and presentations at professional meetings. Furthermore, the results have the potential to reach broader audiences, such as through their inclusion in undergraduate textbooks, and the development of undergraduate teaching labs.

This work will advance the general understanding of the roles that resonance and inductive effects play throughout chemistry. Moreover, the specific results of this project could have far-reaching impacts on rational drug design, and on the understanding of the role that the amino acid arginine has in the initiation and proliferation of certain types of cancer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this reporting period of 06/01/2015 to 11/30/2015, we have one major outcome to report, which is a manuscript that is currently under review by the Journal of Organic Chemistry, entitled: "Why Do Enolate Anions Favor O-Alkylation Over C-Alkylation in the Gas Phase? The Roles of Resonance and Inductive Effects in the Gas-Phase SN2 Reaction Between the Acetaldehyde Enolate Anion and Methyl Fluoride." We have two other manuscripts that are at the beginning of the preparation stage, which were also supported by this NSF grant.

Throughout the life of the grant, we have had three other major publications:

1. Rawlings, R. E.,* McKerlie, A. K.,* Bates, D. J.,* Mo, Y.,* Karty, J. M. “Origin of the SN2 Benzylic Effect: Contributions by π Delocalization and Field/Inductive Effects.” Eur. J. Org. Chem., 2012, 30, 5991-6004.

2. Mo, Y., Basil, A., Guan, L., Karty, J., Mezei, G. “Deprotonation of Methyl-Substituted, Five-Membered Aromatic Molecules: A Surprising Case of Mixed Conjugation, Rehybridization, and Induction Contributions.” Org. Lett. 2014, 16(17), 4680.

3. Lynch, K.,* Maloney, A.,* Sowell, A.,* Wang, C., Mo, Y., Karty, J. M., “Why is Sulfuric Acid a Much Stronger Acid than Methanol? Determination of the Contributions by Inductive/Field Effects and Electron-Delocalization Effects.” Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2015, 17, 138-144.

These three publications and the one that is currently under review all provide insights into the roles that resonance and inductive effects play in different fundamental chemical reactions. The manuscript that is currently under review and publication #1 above were the results of our studies on SN2 reactions. Publications #2 and #3 are the results of studies that probe proton transfer reactions. Both of these reactions are among the most fundamental types of reactions in chemistry. In both reactions, prior to our investigations, the roles that resonance and inductive effects play were believed to have been understood in a qualitative sense only. Our studies have gone well beyond these qualitative understandings to quantiy the contributions of each effect, and have even corrected some significant misunderstandings of the roles that these effects play. For example, in our pubication #1 above, resonance was mistakenly believed to have an insignificant contribution to the benzylic effect.  Moreover, in our publication #3 above, electron delocalization was mistakenly believed to have an insignificant contribution to the strength of sulfuric acid, one of the most important compounds worldwide. By quantifying the effects in both cases, we showed that those effects, to the contrary, have very significant contributions.

As another example, in our publication #2 above, conventional wisdom predicts the favored site of deprotonation on methy-substituted, five-membered aromatic molecules to be different from what is actually observed. By quantifying the roles that resoanance and inductive effects in those systems, we were able to bring the observed results in alignment with a more complete understanding of those systems.

In summary, the intellectual merit of our studies of the contributions by resonance and inductive effects in fundamental chemical systems largely relates to challenging the conventional wisdom of the roles that these effects play. By doing so, we have contributed to a substantially better understanding of these effects, which are prevelant throughout countless chemical systems.


Last Modified: 03/02/2016
Modified by: Joel M Karty
